text.Prompt:
Walmart Canada has taken down its online photo processing store following a "potential compromise of customer credit card data."

The chain said it was recently informed of the potential breach of its Photocentre website.

"We immediately launched an investigation and will be contacting customers who may be impacted," Walmart said. "At this time, we have no reason to believe that Walmart.ca, Walmart.com or in-store transactions are affected. "

The chain has immediately suspended the photo website and all mobile applications pending an investigation. The chains recommends that anyone concerned by the breach should monitor card transactions closely, and immediately alert the financial institution involved about any unauthorized charges.

The Globe and Mail, citing an unnamed source, says as many as 60,000 people could be impacted.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: Walmart Canada has taken down its online photo store after reports that it had been hacked and some 60,000 customer credit card details were stolen.
text.Response B: Walmart Canada has suspended its online photo processing service following reports that customer credit card data may have been compromised. The company has not yet confirmed the breach but has taken the site down, citing "potential compromise of customer credit card data". "We immediately launched an investigation and will be contacting customers who may be impacted," said the company. "At this time, we have no reason to believe that Walmart.ca, Walmart.com or in-store transactions are affected."

The chain said it was recently informed of the potential breach of its Photocentre website.

The Globe and Mail, citing an unnamed source, says as many as 60,000 people could be impacted.

Response A

The company has not yet confirmed the breach but has taken the site down, citing "potential compromise of customer credit card data". "We immediately launched an investigation and will be contacting customers who may be impacted," said the company.
